Accessibilty review of {{product}}

By Intopia for {{client}}

Introduction 

{{client}} engaged Intopia to conduct an independent accessibility review of select features on the update product name. Accessibility is the extent to which a site or app is accessible to as many people as possible. Expert accessibility testers reviewed select pages and features of {{product}} against the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines {{wcag}} {{level}} from {{start}} - {{end}}

How you went 

{{product}} tested very well for accessibility and is a credit to client's time and effort towards making the site accessible. Most of the issues identified were low priority issues, with only a few medium and high priority issues identified.

What you’re doing well

  • The interface is keyboard friendly. Users that rely on the keyboard alone will be able to navigate and operate the interface easily. The focus outline which enables sighted keyboard users to see which component has keyboard focus is clear and applied consistently across the pages tested. 
  •  The sequence and structure of content is generally good. Screen reader users navigate content on a page linearly, making the order of content important. The order of content is consistent and makes it easy for content to be understood. Structural and navigational elements such as headings, lists and links are used well. 

Your most critical issues  

  • Search and Browse form fields are not associated with the correct error messages. This will cause screen reader users to hear the incorrect error message for these fields.   
  • Focus is lost after certain interactions. When information changes dynamically, focus must be set via scripting otherwise focus can be lost and is often placed at a random position on the page. This impacts screen reader users and keyboard only users, who will navigate through content from this random location and be particularly confusing for screen reader users.
